newsitem.title: ESTONIA: ESTONIA SHARES ROAR ON TO NEW HIGHS.
newsitem.headline: ESTONIA SHARES ROAR ON TO NEW HIGHS.

text.p: Hoiupank led the bourse to new highs on Friday and most banking stocks closed higher.
Total trade on the main list was 171 million kroons as the Talse index rose 2.20 percent to close at 422.27.
"Early trade was very nervous as bourse technical problems stopped us from seeing current quotes, but after that the prices just rose quickly," on dealer said.
Hoiupank set the pace during the day as it registered trade of 57.6 million kroons for a new record close of 270 kroons after gaining nine kroons.
"There was no news for Hoiupank today and the rise was too rapid for us to feel comfortable with it," one trader said.
Hoiupank rose by 40.52 percent during the week after a revised profit forecast that saw the bank doubling its earlier prediction for profits growth.
The pace of Hansapank's gains eased slightly to pick up only 1.6 kroons for new record close at 233.50 kroons after 33.8 million kroons changed hands.
Hansa and Hoiu have dominated trade during the past week with Hansa taking 23.6 percent of the week's turnover and Hoiu winning 30.69 percent of the total.
Forekspank regained some ground on news its correspondent account in St Petersburg had been unfrozen.
Along with several other Baltic banks, Forekspank's correspondent accounts were blocked by the St Petersburg tax police, which alleged that the banks owed billions of roubles in unpaid VAT.
A St Petersburg court over-turned the decision on Thursday, Forekspank said.
Foreks closed at 240 kroons, up 16 kroons after turning over 28.7 million kroons.
Tallinna Pank was also affected by the Russian tax police's decision but regained ground after it also announced that it was able to continue operations normally.
Tallinna Pank regained 3.95 kroons to close at 68.95 kroons.
On the free market, total trade was 5.6 million kroons.
Rakvere meat plant was the most active stock with 2.9 million kroons changing hands to be steady at 13 kroons.
